Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: The Vanderbilt-Fisk Interdisciplinary Program for Research and Education in the Nanosciences (VaFIPREN)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Vanderbilt-Fisk Interdisciplinary Program for Research and Education in the Nanosciences is a graduate level program focused on research and graduate student education associated with nanoscale science and engineering. This IGERT program combines the resources of Fisk University and Vanderbilt University in a unique university partnership. Students may enter Vanderbilt and earn a Ph.D., or enter Fisk University, earn a M.S., and then matriculate to the Vanderbilt Ph.D. The intellectual merit is associated with both the research goal - a fundamental and comprehensive approach to the nano-scale science and engineering; and the educational goal- a program, centered in interdisciplinary materials science, to train graduate students to be self-starters and self-learners. Educational and research goals are built on the extensive need for a true interdisciplinary approach required for modern materials science at the nano-scale level. The research theme is the creation, characterization and modeling of nano-structured materials. This is motivated by recent advances in lower dimensionality and creation of unique nanostructures, to access the realm of designed quantum confinement and to realize new materials properties. The educational component comprises a complete background in the interdisciplinary materials sciences which provide the underpinnings of nano-science and nano scale engineering, including current theory, modeling, and experimental practices. IGERT students will be prepared for the fast changing environment associated within nanotechnology. Features of the educational schedule include research rotations, internships, teaching assignments and specialized courses in interdisciplinary nano-science, literature retrieval and science ethics. The broader impact of this project lies in the very strong coupling between Fisk University (a M.S. granting HBCU) and Vanderbilt University. The IGERT is expected to be a significant factor in the cross-fertilization of these two institutions and the stimulation of under-represented groups to participate in nano-scale research and education. In addition we expect the educational aspects of the IGERT to provide a new concept in interdisciplinary education, tuned to the era of nano-scale science and engineering.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries. In this sixth year of the program, awards are being made to institutions for programs that collectively span the areas of science and engineering supported by NSF.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The field of interdisciplinary materials science focuses on the creation and adaption of new materials with enhanced functionality and applications. The field incorporates the research of materials physicists, materials chemists, materials biologists and materials engineers (in almost all sub-disciplines of engineering) for advances in innovative materials. Materials science took a major leap in significance with the realization that manipulation on the nano scale (atomic scale) is possible. This realization gave rise to nanoscience and nanotechnology, namely materials creation from the atomic scale-tailored to demonstrate desired properties. The interdisciplinary nature of the field requires a broad scientific education and was a driving force for the creation of this IGERT. Nanoscale materials play a role in cancer research, in communications and computing through the use of innovative optically and electronically active materials and in energy research incorporating nanostructures in devices such as photovoltaics.
Specific tecnical contributions from this IGERT are listed below:
1) The development of semiconductor nanocrystal (quantum dot) synthesis for extraordinarily high quantum efficient, used in future photovolatics and biomolecule detection..
2) The advanced elemental analysis of semiconductor quantum dots combining scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and Rutherford backscattering for the definitive elemental analysis of these 2-10 nm structures.
3) Demonstration of the Coherent Acoustic Photo-elastic spectroscopy technique (CAP) for the nanoscale determination of the extent of the band-gap modification in the vicinity of crystal defects. Criticla to future memeory technology.
4) Creation of diamond nano-crystal growth methods for new, efficient electron emitters, of potential uses in ultra-fast devices.
5) Development of the electrophoretic deposition technique for the creation of self-supporting nanocrystal structures
7) Development of a new photonic crystal biosensors in collaboration with IBM
8) Demonstration of CdSe ultra-small nanocrystals as 'white light' phosphors for efficient creation of the human acclimated optical spectrum from LEDs
9) Use of metallic (magnetic) nanocrystals for magnetic resonance imaging enhancement.
10) Development of techniques for forming photovoltaic systems out of natural photosynthesis materials.
11) Use of the phase change properties of vanadium dioxide for the development of a new class of optical resonators, applicable to photonics technology

The Vanderbilt-Fisk IGERT is a training program specifically designed to create future scientists, engineers and those able to foster the development of the US STEM workforce.

By virtue of creating over 25 PhD level scientist and engineers we have contributed to the seeding of a diverse array of talent for research, teaching and mentoring in science and engineering areas. One specific example is IGERT Fellow Justin Gregory who, as a result of teaching responsibilities within the IGERT, has chosen an undergraduate teaching career. His exceptional teaching ability, honed through the IGERT, will have a large influence on future STEM individuals.

The Vanderbilt-Fisk IGERT had as an intrinsic component, the matriculation of Fisk University (non-PhD granting HBCU) science students to a PhD program at Vanderbilt. Approximately six such students will complete a PhD through this route. A specific example is Stephen Babalola who received his PhD in 2010 and is now a Research Professor and Lecturer in Materials Science and Engineering at Alabama A&M University (a HBCU).
